standard_metadata.standard_description: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Create equations to solve for missing angles

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A right angle is divided into 2 equal parts, labeled as 35 degrees and 5 X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{35^\circ} +\blueD{5x^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: A right angle is divided into 2 equal parts, labeled as 35 degrees and 5 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A line divides a right angle into two parts labeled as parenthesis open 5 times x plus 30 parenthesis closed degrees and 5 X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{(5x + 30)^\circ} +\blueD{5x^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: A line divides a right angle into two parts labeled as parenthesis open 5 times x plus 30 parenthesis closed degrees and 5 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A line divides a right angle into two parts labeled as x degrees and parenthesis open 6 times x minus 15 parenthesis closed degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{x^\circ} +\blueD{(6x - 15)^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: A line divides a right angle into two parts labeled as x degrees and parenthesis open 6 times x minus 15 parenthesis closed degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A ray divides a right angle into two parts labeled 7 X degrees and 11 X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{7x^\circ} +\blueD{11x ^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: A ray divides a right angle into two parts labeled 7 X degrees and 11 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A ray divides a straight right angle into two parts labeled as x degrees and parenthesis open 4 times x minus 85 parenthesis closed degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{x^\circ} +\blueD{(4x-85) ^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: A ray divides a straight right angle into two parts labeled as x degrees and parenthesis open 4 times x minus 85 parenthesis closed degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight angle into three parts. In clockwise order, the angles are marked as 3 X degrees, parenthesis open 8 times x minus 20 parenthesis closed degrees, and a right angle.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{3x^\circ} +\blueD{(8x-20) ^\circ}= 90^\circ$

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight angle into three parts. In clockwise order, the angles are marked as 3 X degrees, parenthesis open 8 times x minus 20 parenthesis closed degrees, and a right angle.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight angle into three parts labeled as 30 degrees, 2 X degrees and a right angle, from left to right, respectively.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are complementary angles because they combine to form a right angle.
Complementary angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $90^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{2x ^\circ} + \goldD{30^\circ} = 90^\circ$

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight angle into three parts labeled as 30 degrees, 2 X degrees and a right angle, from left to right, respectively.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked and labeled as 4 X degrees. Another angle adjacent to this is marked and labeled as 5 X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{4x^\circ} +\blueD{5x^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked and labeled as 4 X degrees. Another angle adjacent to this is marked and labeled as 5 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersecting each other, are creating supplementary angles of 65 degrees and 2X plus 15 degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{(2x + 15)^\circ} +\blueD{65^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: Two lines intersecting each other, are creating supplementary angles of 65 degrees and 2X plus 15 degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A ray divides a straight angle into two parts. In clockwise order, the angles are marked and labeled as parenthesis open 3 X plus 12 parenthesis closed degrees and X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{(3x + 12)^\circ} +\blueD{x^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: A ray divides a straight angle into two parts. In clockwise order, the angles are marked and labeled as parenthesis open 3 X plus 12 parenthesis closed degrees and X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A ray divides a straight horizontal line into two angles labeled 5 X degrees and 13 X degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{5x^\circ} +\blueD{13x^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: A ray divides a straight horizontal line into two angles labeled 5 X degrees and 13 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight horizontal in three diffrent angles labeled 3 X degrees, 80 degrees, and 2 X degrees, from left to right, respectively.

hints.content: The three labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{3x^\circ} +\blueD{80^\circ} +\maroonD{2x^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: Two rays divide a straight horizontal in three diffrent angles labeled 3 X degrees, 80 degrees, and 2 X degrees, from left to right, respectively.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: A straight horizontal line is perpendicular to a straight vertical ray. One of the two angles made by the line and the ray is divided into unequal parts by another ray. The measurements of these unequal angles are 6 X degrees and 12 X degrees.

hints.content: The three labeled angles are supplementary angles because they combine to form a straight line.
Supplementary angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.  So, the labeled angles have a sum of $180^\circ$.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{6x^\circ} +\blueD{12x^\circ} + \maroonD{90^\circ}= 180^\circ$

images.alt: A straight horizontal line is perpendicular to a straight vertical ray. One of the two angles made by the line and the ray is divided into unequal parts by another ray. The measurements of these unequal angles are 6X degrees, and 12X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersecting each other, are creating opposite angles of 60 degrees and X plus 45 degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are congruent.   So, the labeled angle measures are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{60^\circ} = \blueD{(x+45)^\circ}$

images.alt: Two lines intersecting each other, are creating opposite angles of 60 degrees and X plus 45 degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as parenthesis open 5 times x minus 70 parenthesis closed degrees. Another angle opposite to this is marked as 105 degrees.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are congruent.   So, the labeled angle measures are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{105^\circ} = \blueD{(5x-70)^\circ}$

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as parenthesis open 5 times x minus 70 parenthesis closed degrees. Another angle opposite to this is marked as 105 degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersect at a single point. Two lines are create angles labeled as 60 degrees and 4 X minus 20 degrees opposite to each other.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are congruent.   So, the labeled angle measures are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{60^\circ} = \blueD{(4x-20)^\circ}$

images.alt: Two slant lines and a ray intersect at a single point. Two lines are create angles labeled as 60 degrees and 4 X minus 20 degrees opposite to each other.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 30 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is labeled as parenthesis open 3 times x parenthesis closed degrees. The angle between these two is divided by a ray into two parts.

hints.content: The two labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are equivalent.   So, the labeled angles are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{3x^\circ} = \blueD{30^\circ}$

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 30 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is labeled as parenthesis open 3 times x parenthesis closed degrees. The angle between these two is divided by a ray into two parts.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 110 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is marked and labeled as parenthesis open 10 times x plus 10 parenthesis closed degrees. The angle between these two is divided by a ray into two parts.

hints.content: The labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are congruent.   So, the labeled angle measures are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{(10x+10)^\circ} = \blueD{110^\circ}$

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 110 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is marked and labeled as parenthesis open 10 times x plus 10 parenthesis closed degrees. The angle between these two is divided by a ray into two parts.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 150 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is divided by a ray into two parts labeled 2 X degrees and 4 X degrees.

hints.content: $\goldD{2x^\circ}$ and  $\maroonD{4x^\circ}$ combine to form an angle that is opposite the $\blueD{150^\circ}$ angle where two lines meet.  This means $\goldD{2x^\circ}$ combined with  $\maroonD{4x^\circ}$ and $\blueD{150^\circ}$ are vertical angles.
Vertical angles are equivalent.   So, the labeled angles are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{2x^\circ} + \maroonD{4x^\circ}= \blueD{150^\circ} $

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is marked as 150 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is divided by a ray into two parts labeled 2 X degrees and 4 X degrees.

question.content: **Which equation can be used to solve for $x$ in the following diagram?**

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is labeled as 150 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is labeled as 10 X degrees.

hints.content: The labeled angles are vertical angles because they are opposite each other where two lines cross.
Vertical angles are equivalent.   So, the labeled angles are equivalent.
[[☃ image 1]]  $\goldD{10x^\circ} = \blueD{150^\circ} $

images.alt: Two lines intersect forming angles. One of the angles is labeled as 150 degrees. Another angle opposite to this is labeled as 10 X degrees.
